intro: Senecio papposus, commonly known as the desert parsley or desert dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble dandelions. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer, followed by fluffy, white to pale yellow seeds that are easily dispersed by the wind. Senecio papposus is adapted to harsh desert conditions, with deep roots and a low, sprawling growth habit to conserve water. Its leaves are finely divided and aromatic, often used in traditional medicine by indigenous peoples.
